channel.title: S. Sharma's Blog
channel.description: Recent content on S. Sharma's Blog

item.title: Privating Repos
item.description: Recently, I went ahead and private some of my repositories, including repositories of projects that I’m currently working on. I just wanted to quickly explain why I’m doing this. I’ve always wanted to hold myself accountable for the projects I do. Sometimes, when I do a project, I can become uninterested in what I’m doing or I’ll hold off on it due to other responsibilities. As a result, this leaves me with plenty of repositories, some of which are completed projects and others that are not.

item.title: An Interesting Fact About Logarithms
item.description: Today I learned something interesting about logarithms. Namely, that: $$\lg x \approx \ln x + \log x$$ with less than 1% error! The “proof” behind this is as follows: $$\frac{\ln x + \log x}{\lg x} = \frac{\frac{\lg x}{\lg e} + \frac{\lg x}{\lg 10}}{\lg x}$$ $$= \frac{(\lg e + \lg 10)(\lg x)}{\lg x \lg 10 \lg e}$$ $$= \frac{1}{\lg e} + \frac{1}{\lg 10}$$ $$ = \ln 2+ \log 2 $$ The above is approximately equivalent to $0.

item.title: Happy New Years
item.description: Hey there. It’s been a while since I’ve last written. Hopefully I’ll be able to write more this year. That’s it. Tomorrow, I plan on making a post. Happy new years! :)

item.title: Reddit Upvote Predictor Part 1
item.description: Hey there. I wanted to start working more with Tensorflow, so I decided to do a simple project where I try to predict the number of upvotes a given Reddit post will receive in a certain amount of time. This project is very suitable for machine learning, since the number of upvotes $y$ that a post gets can be predicted using a linear equation, of the form $\sum_{i=1}^n w_ix_i+b_i$ where $w_i$ and $b_i$ can be calculated through a method such as gradient descent and $x_i$ is the feature in particular.

item.title: Quick Update Again
item.description: Hey there. I haven’t been writing recently because I got busy with school/work and felt too tired to write anything. I’m hoping that this week I can start writing everyday again. :)

item.title: Getting a MAC Address on a Mac
item.description: Hey there. Recently, I needed to write some code in C to get the MAC address of a particular interface. On Linux, this is pretty easy to do. However, on BSD systems and, more importantly, on macOS, it wasn’t as straightforward and I had to do some digging to find an answer. On Linux, generally I would find the MAC address by doing an ioctl() call with the argument SIOCGIFHWADDR like so:

item.title: Unfinished Projects
item.description: Hey there. I dropped writing for a little bit just to give myself a break and give myself some time to work on my project. Speaking of projects, this year I’ve been trying to cultivate more persistence. I feel like in the past I would start a project, go somewhat far with it, and then fail to follow through and provide something that worked the way I wanted. More critically, I didn’t feel satisfied.

item.title: Learning Rust
item.description: Hey there. I didn’t want to write yesterday because I was working on my project. In other news, I decided to learn a little bit of Rust through the Official Rust Book since I used to play around with the C programming language. So far, I’ve found Rust to be an interesting language that remedies some of the problems with “unsafe” languages like C while still attempting to give access to the low level.

item.title: Watson Time Tracker
item.description: I was working on my project today and I decided to try out a tool that I’ve been interested in using for a long time. Watson is a time management tracker that you can use to track how much time you spend on your projects. Today, according to Watson, I spent 1 hour and 11 minutes working on my project. I hope to use it more to track my time and hopefully in the future I can talk about the benefits/cons of using something like Watson.

item.title: Wikipedia Graph Update
item.description: I wanted to give a quick update on the project that I’ve been working on. Today, I managed to render the nodes and links on the canvas and I think I also have a better understanding of D3.js than before. Of course, I think some optimizations can be made and it can be made more graphically appealing (labels on the nodes and drag/pan/zoom are two features that I definitely want to implement soon).
